name: tantalum mine operation and beneficiation | tantalum concentrate, 30% Ta2O5 | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24665/documentation

This dataset refers to the mining and beneficiation activities in order to produce 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5) in Rwanda. Rwanda is responsible for 20.6% of the global mine production (Source: https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2020/mcs2020-tantalum.pdf). This dataset is a disaggregation of the activity ''tantalum production, powder, capacitor-grade'' as found in version 3.7 of the Ecoinvent database that produces tantalum powder from tantalite ore and has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography GLO, due to absence of regionalized dataset.;Specific values (such as i) average ore grade for the RW geography - 0.03302% instead of 0.0194% Ta2O5 - and consequently the amount of extracted ore from the ground, ii) the ore grade of the concentrate from 38% to 30% to represent today's situation as the grade of the concentrate 20-40 years ago was 40-45%) were changed to provide a more representative picture of the today's tantalum concentrate production. Furthermore, values such as electricity, water and diesel consumption were scaled based on the new amount of ore extracted from ground (approximately 1245 kg) and grade of the final concentrate to ensure better representativeness (for more information consult the sampling procedure and the respective exchanges comments). Regarding the grades of the extracted tantalite ore, due to lack of data about the grade of ore deposits in Rwanda, the grades of 5 mines from Mozambique and Namibia are considered here as the best approximation, resulting in an average grade of 0.03302% (Source: Table M4 page M13 of the following link: https://pubs.usgs.gov/pp/1802/m/pp1802m.pdf - for more detailed information, see tantalum, in ground elementary flow comment).;The original data are based on the Grenbushes and Wodgina mines in Western Australia. The original data and their underlying assumptions can be found in chapter 5.1.2, tables 5.2 & 5.3, part XI of the Classen et al (2009) report. Only production from tantalite ore and through open-pit mining is considered here, meaning that mining of tantalum from other ores (such as pyrochlore) or through other mining techniques (such artisanal mining) are not taken into account.;;Reference: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.

The activities start with the mining of the tantalum ore.

The activities end with the production of tantalum concentrate (30% beneficiated).

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset considered valid for the entire corresponding region.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: At first, the tantalum minerals are extracted from the ground through open-pit mining. Standard pro-cess include drilling, blasting, and muck cycles prior to the beneficiation of the tantalum ore. After min-ing, tantalite ores are almost exclusively concentrated through wet gravity concentration, utilizing equipment such as jigs, spirals and tables, in order to produce low- to medium-grade concentrate. Centrifugal type concentrators could be used in the future to recover even finer tantalum particles, but there is no indication that the industry is moving towards that direction. The low- to medium-grade concentrates are further beneficiated in dry plants, where dry gravity concentrators, magnetic and elec-trostatic concentrators are used and sulfides are ocassionally removed by flotation. The tantalum con-tent of the resulting concentrate is usually between 25-35% (Source: Rob-ert Linnen, D.L. Trueman, Richard BurtTantalum and niobium Gunn, Gus (Eds.), 2014, Critical Metals Handbook: British Geological Survey (2014), pp. 361-384) or 20-40% Ta2O5 (according to figure 15.6 of the same source), which is lower than the required grade in the past (45-50% % Ta2O5). In general, concentrates from central Africa have higher Ta2O5 grades than those produced in Canada, Brazil or Australia.  However due to lack of data it is assumed that the average grade of Ta2O5 is 30%.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is meant to be an average representation of the tantalum mining in Rwanda. The original data provided originated from the Greenbushes & Wodgina mines in Western Australia and were used as best available representation, since the production process of the concentrate has not changed over the years (see sampling procedure). Conveyor belt for the transport of the ore was approximated with the one used in the copper datasets. Uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset refers to the mining and beneficiation activities in order to produce 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5) in Rwanda. Rwanda is responsible for 20.6% of the global mine production (Source: https://pubs.usgs.gov/periodicals/mcs2020/mcs2020-tantalum.pdf). This dataset is a disaggregation of the activity ''tantalum production, powder, capacitor-grade'' as found in version 3.7 of the Ecoinvent database that produces tantalum powder from tantalite ore and has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography GLO, due to absence of regionalized dataset.

Specific values (such as i) average ore grade for the RW geography - 0.03302% instead of 0.0194% Ta2O5 - and consequently the amount of extracted ore from the ground, ii) the ore grade of the concentrate from 38% to 30% to represent today's situation as the grade of the concentrate 20-40 years ago was 40-45%) were changed to provide a more representative picture of the today's tantalum concentrate production. Furthermore, values such as electricity, water and diesel consumption were scaled based on the new amount of ore extracted from ground (approximately 1245 kg) and grade of the final concentrate to ensure better representativeness (for more information consult the sampling procedure and the respective exchanges comments). Regarding the grades of the extracted tantalite ore, due to lack of data about the grade of ore deposits in Rwanda, the grades of 5 mines from Mozambique and Namibia are considered here as the best approximation, resulting in an average grade of 0.03302% (Source: Table M4 page M13 of the following link: https://pubs.usgs.gov/pp/1802/m/pp1802m.pdf - for more detailed information, see tantalum, in ground elementary flow comment).

The original data are based on the Grenbushes and Wodgina mines in Western Australia. The original data and their underlying assumptions can be found in chapter 5.1.2, tables 5.2 & 5.3, part XI of the Classen et al (2009) report. Only production from tantalite ore and through open-pit mining is considered here, meaning that mining of tantalum from other ores (such as pyrochlore) or through other mining techniques (such artisanal mining) are not taken into account.

Reference: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.

flow.name: tantalum concentrate, 30% Ta2O5
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE
The original value is 155466 kWh and represents tha amount of electricity consumption required for the production of 1000 kg of tantalum pentoxide content in the concentrate (or 2632 kg of concentrate), with a grade of 38% Ta2O5. These original values were taken from Table 5.3, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. The amount of electricity was first adjusted to correspond to the production of 1 kg of tantalite ore (by diving the amount of electricity consumption by 7067000 kg of ore - same source as mentioned above). The resulting value was then multiplied with 1245, as 1245 kg of tantalite ore are required for the production of 1 kg of concentrate with a grade of 30% Ta2O5 (see gangue, in ground exchange comment).

exchanges.description:
The value represents the amount of tantalum that needs to be extracted from the ground for the production of 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5). This value is obtained by multiplying the amount of tantalum ore extracted from the ground (1245 kg - more information on the gangue exchange comment) with i) the grade of tantalum contained in the ore and ii) the subtotal mass of tantalum in Ta2O5. The average ore grade for Rwanda is calculated the following way: Due to lack of data about the grade of ore deposits in Rwanda, the grades of mines from Mozambique and Namibia are considered here (Source: Table M4 page M13 of the following link: <https://pubs.usgs.gov/pp/1802/m/pp1802m.pdf>). The average grade of these 5 mines is considered as the grade of tantalum in the ore in Congo.  

Mine	    Ore Grades (% Ta2O5)	Country	
Marropino             0.0223	                Mozambique	
Morrua	             0.0248	                Mozambique	
Muiane	             0.025	                Mozambique	
Tantalite Valley     0.043	                Namibia	
Three aloes          0.05	                Namibia	
Average	             0.03302	                Average for Rwanda	
The subtotal masses of Ta2O5 are: Ta:81.90% , O:18.90%.

Land use value is 7.85E-02 m2 / t ore. Value is taken fromTable 5.2, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.This value was originally obtained from a report from the company Sons of Galia.Exchange considered based on Table 5.3 of the same chapter and ecoinvent report listed above. The amount of ore extracted for the production of 1 kg of concentrate is 1245 kg (see gangue, in ground comment).

The land occupation value is 7.85E-02 m2a/ t ore is taken fromTable 5.2, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. However, after internal review within Ecoinvent, there may be wrong reporting of the value in the abovementioned source, For this exchange, it is assumed that the units of the value is in m2 / t ore instead of m2*year / t ore as originally reported. Therefore, the value has to be multiplied by 50, since the mine is assumed to be operating for 50 years. The original value originated from the company Sons of Galia.The amount of ore extracted for the production of 1 kg of concentrate is 1245 kg (see gangue, in ground comment).

EcoSpold01Location=GLO
The original value is 828720 MJ and represents tha amount of diesel consumption required for the production of 1000 kg of tantalum pentoxide content in the concentrate (or 2632 kg of concentrate), with a grade of 38% Ta2O5. These original values were taken from Table 5.3, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. The amount of diesel was first adjusted to correspond to the production of 1 kg of tantalite ore (by diving the amount of diesel consumption by 7067000 kg of ore - same source as mentioned above). The resulting value was then multiplied with 1245, as 1245 kg of tantalite ore are required for the production of 1 kg of concentrate with a grade of 30% Ta2O5 (see gangue, in ground exchange comment).

exchanges.description: The value represents the amount of gangue that is extracted from the ground for the production of 1 kg of tantalum concentrate (30% Ta2O5). This value is obtained by subtracting the amount of tantalum extracted from the ore (0.336575 kg-see tantalum, in ground comment) from the amount of total ore that is extracted from the ground. The latter amount is calculated based on the following facts: i) The average ore grade in Congo is 0.03302% Ta2O5 (see tantalum in ground comment). ii) The recovery efficiency of tantalum during mining and beneficiation is between 72%-74% (Source: Roethe, G. (1989). Processing of Tantalum and Niobium Ores, Berlin, Heidelberg). The average value of 73% is considered here and iii) the concentrate ore grade is 30% Ta2O5. This results approximately in an amount of approximately 1245 kg of extracted tantalite ore.

Infrastructural input considered for the mining of tantalite ore. The amount of input was based on the following assumptions: i) 400000 tons of ore output per year ii) infrastructure lifetime of 50 years and iii) 1245 kg of tantalite ore are required for the production of 1 kg of concentrate (see gangue, in ground exchange comment).
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

exchanges.description: The original value is 5212 m3 and represents tha amount of water consumption required for the production of 1000 kg of tantalum pentoxide content in the concentrate (or 2632 kg of concentrate), with a grade of 38% Ta2O5.These original values were taken from Table 5.3, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. The amount of water was first adjusted to correspond to the production of 1 kg of tantalite ore (by diving the amount of water consumption by 7067000 kg of ore - same source as mentioned above). The resulting value was then multiplied with 1245, as 1245 kg of tantalite ore are required for the production of 1 kg of concentrate with a grade of 30% Ta2O5 (see gangue, in ground exchange comment).

Land use value is 7.85E-02 m2 / t ore. Value is taken fromTable 5.2, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch.This value was originally obtained from a report from the company Sons of Galia.Exchange considered based on Table 5.3 of the same chapter and ecoinvent report listed above. The amount of ore extracted for the production of 1 kg of concentrate is 1245 kg (see gangue, in ground comment).

The amount of PM>10 um is calculated by subtracting the amount of PM10  from TSP (total suspended solids). TSP = 101.72 g / t ore PM10 = 50 g / t ore. The values for TSP and PM10 are taken fromTable 5.2, chapter 11 of the following report: Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S.,Tuchschmid M., Jungbluth N., Doka G., Faist Emmenegger M. and Scharnhorst W. (2009) Life Cycle lnventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle lnventories, Dübendorf , CH, Online-Version under: www .ecoinvent.ch. This value was originally obtained from the CEMPEIP database. The amount of ore extracted for the production of 1 kg of concentrate is 1245 kg (see gangue, in ground comment).
